label: Initialize Settings
info:
When clients first connect, send settings events with default values if
no retained settings are found.

label: Hue
info:
Interoperate with Philips Hue Bridges using local API. See <https://developers.meethue.com/develop/hue-api-v2/getting-started/> for more information.

This flow:

- Uses mDNS to discover Hue bridges on the LAN and publishes
  corresponding `hue/bridges` event messages for use by the dashboard's
  front-end logic

- Contains two instances of the _Hue API V2_ subflow, one each for
  the Hue bridges specified by the `${GROUND_FLOOR_HUE_ADDRESS}` and
  `${BASEMENT_HUE_ADDRESS}` environment variables

label: PowerView
info:
Interoperate with the PowerView hub whose IP address is specified by the
`${POWERVIEW_ADDRESS}` environment variable.

This flow obtains the current configuration data from the hub and
publishes an event message whose `msg.topic` is `powerview/model`
and whose `msg.payload` contains a JSON object with the structure
expected by the front-end code for the dashboard. It also subscribes
to `put/powerview/scene` messages and activates the PowerView scenes
indicated by their payloads.

## PowerView® API

Note that despite what the official documentation says, it is also
possible to query a list of rooms, in addition to the documented query
for listing scenes. See [Undocumented Feature](#undocumented-feature),
below.

Here is a snapshot of
<https://motorisation.hde.nl/hd/powerview/general-guides/API/>
as of March 17, 2024:

> ---
> To connect a PowerView® system to a home automation system a
> PowerView® Hub is required.
>
> The current hub implementation supports an HTTP REST API which is
> described in this document. If you have an older hub, it is also
> possible to make use of the API through a serial connection, which is
> described here
>
> Currently the API is limited to commands for getting a list of scenes
> and commands to activate scenes. These scenes need to be created in the
> PowerView® app first. When receiving a list of scenes from the hub the
> scene names are base64 encoded. For proper identification they need to
> be programmatically converted to unicode utf-8 readable text. Go
> [here](https://www.base64decode.org/) for an online converter. Go
> [here](#base64_encoding) for some code examples.
>
> ---
> **PowerView® HTTP API**
>
>> **IMPORTANT**
>>
>> Make sure your hub gets a reserved/fixed ip address from the dhcp
>> server.
>>
>> The preferred method of setting a fixed IP address is IP address
>> reservation based on MAC address in the home router (which should be
>> the router with the dhcp server running)
>>
>> The hub ip and MAC address can be found using the PowerView app:
>>
>> 1. Open the side menu.
>> 2. Select <Hub>
>> 3. Select the currently connected hub
>> 4. Select <hub info>
>>
>> A list should appear with both ip and MAC address displayed.
>
> ---
> **Get a list of all available scenes**
>
> request:
>
> method: `GET`
>
> `api/scenes/`
>
> response example:
>
> ```
> {
>   "sceneIds":[7214,64073,15890,42747],
>   "sceneData":[
>     {
>       "id":7214,
>       "name":"QWxsIGRvd24=", //base64 encoded.
>       "roomId":64902,
>       "order":0,
>       "colorId":2,
>       "iconId":0
>     },
>     {
>       "id":64073,
>       "name":"UGxpc3NlIDE=", //base64 encoded.
>       "roomId":64902,
>       "order":1,
>       "colorId":5,
>       "iconId":0
>     },
>     {
>       "id":15890,
>       "name":"QWxsIHVw", //base64 encoded.
>       "roomId":64902,
>       "order":2,
>       "colorId":0,
>       "iconId":0
>     },
>     {
>       "id":42747,
>       "name":"UGxpc3NlIDI=", //base64 encoded.
>       "roomId":64902,
>       "order":3,
>       "colorId":7,
>       "iconId":0
>     }
>   ]
> }
> ```
>
> ---
> **Activate a scene**
>
> request:
>
> method: `GET`
>
> `/api/scenes?sceneId=<sceneid>`  //replace <sceneid> with actual scene id.
>
> response example:
>
> ```
> {
>   "scene":{"shadeIds":[35523]}
> }
> ```
>
> **Base64 encoding**
>
> **Python**
>
> ```python
> import base64
>
> def decode_base64(str):
>     """Convert base64 to unicode text"""
>     return base64.b64decode(str).decode('utf-8')
> ```
>
> **javascript**
>
> ```javascript
> function decode_base64(str){
>   // Converts incoming base64 to unicode text.
>   return new Buffer(str, 'base64').toString('binary');
> }
> ```

### Undocumented Feature

**Get a list of all available rooms**

request: `GET`

`api/rooms`

response example:

```
{
    "roomIds":[
        12345,
        56789
    ],
    "roomData":[
        {
            "order":13,
            "name":"pR9Yj2g=",
            "colorId":3,
            "iconId":50,
            "type":0,
            "id":12345
        },
        {
            "order":10,
            "name":"GhH357==",
            "colorId":3,
            "iconId":50,
            "type":0,
            "id":56789
        }
    ]
}
```

info:
Dynamically create dashboard buttons corresponding to each scene
discovered by querying a _PowerView_ hub.

name: send commands to the powerview hub at a rate of no more than 1 per second
websocket based publish / subscribe message broker with semantics inspired by mqtt
info:
Broadcast messages received from any client to all clients. Note that
all properties other than `msg._session` and `msg.retain` are
transmitted directly from the publisher to all subscribers.

- Removes `msg._session` entirely, in the case of initially published
  messages.

- Handles `msg.topic` and `msg.retain` in a fashion inspired by MQTT.

If a client publishes a message with `msg.retain` set to `true`, the
`retain` function node saves a clone of the message in flow context
using a file-system backed context store using `msg.topic` as the key.
It then sets `msg.retain` to `false` before broadcasting the message
to subscribed clients.

Each time a client connects, the `retained` function node sends that
client all currently stored messages with `msg.retain` set to `true`.

Retained messages' contents can be updated by sending subsequent
messages with the same `msg.topic` and `msg.retain` set to `true`.

Retained messages can be deleted by sending subsequent messages with
the same `msg.topic`, `msg.retain` set to `true` and `msg.payload`
set to the empty string (`''`).

name: send timer events over the course of each day
info:
Subscribe to settings change events. Send `automation/trigger` events up
to five times per day, at: sunrise, the start of midday, the start of
afternoon, sunset and bedtime.

- The times for sunrise and sunset are obtained directly from
  [`suncalc.getTimes()`](https://github.com/mourner/suncalc#sunlight-times)

- The times for midday and afternoon are determined using the position
  of the sun over the course of the current day as reported by
  [`suncalc.getPosition()`](https://github.com/mourner/suncalc#sun-position)

- The time for bedtime varies randomly each day, as described below

The `${LATITUDE}` and `${LONGITUDE}` environment variables must be set
to the home's geographic coordinates for use with `suncalc`.

Midday starts when the sun first reaches an altitude of 0.8 radians. No
midday will be sent on a given day if the sun never reaches that
altitude for the specified `${LATITUDE}`.

Afternoon starts when the sun's azimuth is greater than 0 and its
altitude first drops below 0.8 radians. For days on which the altitude
never reaches 0.8, this will be as soon after sunrise as the sun starts
to shine more from the west than the east.

Bedtime is randomized each day, constrained to be within ±30
minutes of the value for `settings/bedtime`.

Note that the inclusion of midday and afternoon and the rules for
determining when they occur on a given day were determined empirically
for a particular house with 4 parallel walls, aligned more or less
exactly with the cardinal compass directions at a particular latitude.
It is also influenced by the size of that house's rather substantial
eaves shading the east- and west-facing windows. They might need
adjustment or an entirely different set of events for a different
structure at a different location. The goal of all this is to trigger
automation to control lighting and motorized window coverings in such
a way that maximizes the times of day at which the view of the outside
world can be enjoyed while optimizing the lighting and window coverings
for comfort and energy efficiency during times of day when the sun
shines too directly into the windows.

Activate the corresponding PowerView scene upon receipt of of each

name: retrieve and parse metadata for a specified type of resource from a given PowerView hub
clone
func: return RED.util.cloneMessage(msg)

name: commands
send retained
info:
Send all currently retained messages to each client as it connects.

Each message received by this node must include a websocket session in
`msg.status._session`. The output will be a succession of messages,
each of which is a clone of a currently retained message, with
`msg._session` set to the input message's `msg.status._session` and
`msg.retain` set to `true`.

name: retain
info:
Maintain a repository of retained messages in flow context using a
context store named `file`, which is assumed to be file-system backed.

For each input `msg`:

1. If and only if `msg.retain` is `true`,
   - If `msg.payload` is the empty string, delete the current value of `msg.topic` from the retained message repository
   - Otherwise, set the value of `msg.topic` in the retained message repository to `msg`
2. Output a clone of `msg` with `msg.retain` set to `false`

name: assumes a file-system backed context store named "file"

info:
Synchronize receipt of `daily/timestamp` and `settings/bedtime`
messages.

name: timer
info:
# Input

- `msg.payload.now` - timestamp at which flows started and again each day
   at 1am

- `msg.payload.settings/bedtime` - _bedtime_ value selected by a user
  on the dashboard

# Output

Up to five 'timer/time` messages per day and one `timer/theme` message.

# Details

## Time

When the output `msg.topic` is `timer/time`, `msg.payload` will be one
of:

- `sunrise`
- `midday`
- `afternoon`
- `sunset`
- `bedtime`

In addition, `msg.at` will be set to the timestamp at which the
corresponding event message should actually be published. See the
documentation for the following `delay until` function node for
information on when the `timer/time` events will actually fire based
on their values for `msg.at`.

## Theme

When the output `msg.topic` is `timer/theme`, `msg.payload` will be one
of the following values based on the date:

- `tribal`
- `spooky`
- `jolly`
- `standard`

func: rbe

name: delay until
info:
Delay messages until a particular time has been reached.

Messages are passed through unchanged but may be delayed based on the
value of `msg.at`. If `msg.at` is present, it must indicate an
absolute time in a format compatible with JavaScript's `new Date(time)`
constructor. If that time is in the future, this function will delay
forwarding the given message until the specified time has been reached.

If `msg.at` is missing or indicates a time that is the same or earlier
than "now" (`new Date()` with no argument) then the message is passed
through with no delay.

If a message arrives with `msg.cancel` set to `true`, all pending
messages are canceled without being sent.

> **Warning:** Delays are implemented using `setTimeout()`. This means
that while this node will emit messages no earlier than the time
specified by `msg.at`, they will actually be delivered some (typically
tiny) amount of time later based on the overhead of any computer
program combined with the fact that Node-RED flows are intrinsically
single-threaded. Ultra-precise timers require real-time programming
techniques driven by specialized hardware.

Note that it would require only a bit more work to support a `msg.flush`
that would immediately send all pending messages rather than canceling
them, but there is no use case for such a feature in these flows.

Canceling or flushing only a particular message without canceling or
flushing them all would require a lot more work and a second output.
That is far more effort than it is worth given the probable use cases
for a node like this in the first place.

Block `automation/trigger` until after all three of `settings/shades`,
`settings/lighting` and `timer/theme` have all been received.

Open All Shades

name: timer/theme
info: Trigger evening lighting automation for the specified _theme_.

name: lighting automation event
debug trigger
func:
const debug = RED.util.cloneMessage(msg)

debug.topic = 'debug/' + debug.topic
debug.retain = true
debug.payload.timestamp = new Date().toLocaleString()

return [
    [msg, debug]
]
rbe

info:
## Docmented API

Here is a snapshot of
<https://motorisation.hde.nl/hd/powerview/general-guides/API/>
as of March 17, 2024:

> ---
> To connect a PowerView® system to a home automation system a
> PowerView® Hub is required.
>
> The current hub implementation supports an HTTP REST API which is
> described in this document. If you have an older hub, it is also
> possible to make use of the API through a serial connection, which is
> described here
>
> Currently the API is limited to commands for getting a list of scenes
> and commands to activate scenes. These scenes need to be created in the
> PowerView® app first. When receiving a list of scenes from the hub the
> scene names are base64 encoded. For proper identification they need to
> be programmatically converted to unicode utf-8 readable text. Go
> [here](https://www.base64decode.org/) for an online converter. Go
> [here](#base64_encoding) for some code examples.
>
> ---
> **PowerView® HTTP API**
>
>> **IMPORTANT**
>>
>> Make sure your hub gets a reserved/fixed ip address from the dhcp
>> server.
>>
>> The preferred method of setting a fixed IP address is IP address
>> reservation based on MAC address in the home router (which should be
>> the router with the dhcp server running)
>>
>> The hub ip and MAC address can be found using the PowerView app:
>>
>> 1. Open the side menu.
>> 2. Select <Hub>
>> 3. Select the currently connected hub
>> 4. Select <hub info>
>>
>> A list should appear with both ip and MAC address displayed.
>
> ---
> **Get a list of all available scenes**
>
> request:
>
> method: `GET`
>
> `api/scenes/`
>
> response example:
>
> ```
> {
>   "sceneIds":[7214,64073,15890,42747],
>   "sceneData":[
>     {
>       "id":7214,
>       "name":"QWxsIGRvd24=", //base64 encoded.
>       "roomId":64902,
>       "order":0,
>       "colorId":2,
>       "iconId":0
>     },
>     {
>       "id":64073,
>       "name":"UGxpc3NlIDE=", //base64 encoded.
>       "roomId":64902,
>       "order":1,
>       "colorId":5,
>       "iconId":0
>     },
>     {
>       "id":15890,
>       "name":"QWxsIHVw", //base64 encoded.
>       "roomId":64902,
>       "order":2,
>       "colorId":0,
>       "iconId":0
>     },
>     {
>       "id":42747,
>       "name":"UGxpc3NlIDI=", //base64 encoded.
>       "roomId":64902,
>       "order":3,
>       "colorId":7,
>       "iconId":0
>     }
>   ]
> }
> ```
>
> ---
> **Activate a scene**
>
> request:
>
> method: `GET`
>
> `/api/scenes?sceneId=<sceneid>`  //replace <sceneid> with actual scene id.
>
> response example:
>
> ```
> {
>   "scene":{"shadeIds":[35523]}
> }
> ```
>
> **Base64 encoding**
>
> **Python**
>
> ```python
> import base64
>
> def decode_base64(str):
>     """Convert base64 to unicode text"""
>     return base64.b64decode(str).decode('utf-8')
> ```
>
> **javascript**
>
> ```javascript
> function decode_base64(str){
>   // Converts incoming base64 to unicode text.
>   return new Buffer(str, 'base64').toString('binary');
> }
> ```

name: powerview url
func:
return {
    payload: null,
    url: 'http://' +
        env.get('POWERVIEW_ADDRESS') +
        '/api/scenes?sceneId=' +
        msg.payload
}
